reviews.reviewTitle: Engine burned out in less than 6 months
reviews.reviewText: I got this as a replacement for my original coffee grinder that I got as a wedding gift 25 years ago. Yes, 25 years ago and it's STILL grinding, although one of the ends of the blades broke off so I decided to upgrade and get a new grinder. I picked this one up from Walmart. Unfortunately they didn't have my particular brand, so I figured I'd give the Hamilton Beach a try. Great price and it's really quiet compared to my old one, and it's a little faster to grind than the old one. BUT, it is a downright shame when a product doesn't last more than a few months with normal standard everyday use. I can't say that we will purchase this product again. We don't have to have the biggest or the best or most expensive, but we want our money to count and the products we buy to last, not just consume and throw away. We're just very disappointed with yet another CHEAP product.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Perfect Grinder: Extremely fast and elegantly simple
reviews.reviewText: After my fancier grinders broke down several times, I bought this very inexpensive little grinder and I love it more than any I've ever owned. With just 4-5 quick pumps on the button the beans are ground. (It's easy to see grind size through the lid as you grind.) One small twist and the inner cup comes out allowing you to dump your grounded beans into the filter. For those reviews that complain the ground beans over flow the cup when you take the lid off: Just give the grinder a few small shakes or taps to settle the beans into the cup before you take off the lid. Problem solved.

If you're looking for an inexpensive coffee grinder, move on. This is not for you. I have had this grinder for some time now, well over a year. I finally broke down and got another brand, and finally decided to write a review.

Don't get me wrong. It grinds. Problem is, it doesn't grind evenly or thoroughly. I've tried everything. Stopping and starting. Tilting. Shaking. Full load. Half load. It NEVER gets all of the beans. There are always a few whole beans left, camouflaged by the rest of the coffee grounds. They are more visible after pouring into my storage container, or after making coffee and looking into the leftover grounds. That equates to wasted money over time, since a whole bean cannot allow water to infuse and extract flavor, forcing you to use more coffee.

Bottom line: this product is poorly designed and you should not purchase. Looks good on the shelf though, where it will stay until I take it Goodwill.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best grinder I have ever used
reviews.reviewText: I bought this, even though I already had a good grinder, solely because of the advertised low noise. I and others in my family are very sensitive to our grating noises and were always subjected to a brief moment of stress every morning. zit was with great relief the first time we used it to see that they loud grating noise was now merely a gentle hum. Very easy to clean ( the inside pulls out) and you can have any grind you want by how long you have it running) Top cap pulls off easily. I jut bought this for a friend. The first one I bought over a year ago and with regular use several times every day it still works as new.

This product is great. I can easily make fresh coffee every morning and it only takes an extra 30 seconds if that to grind up the beans. As expected with any grinder, you do get some bean powder here and there but it’s an easy clean with a simple wipe. The cover and the blades are easy to clean and I sometimes throw them into the dishwasher. I like the safety feature that you need to line it up correctly and the lid must be on in order for you to push the button for it to work but I still keep the parts in separate areas as an added safer havens step so my kids don’t get into it. I highly recommend this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Didn't last 1-yr. Skip it & get something stronger.
reviews.reviewText:
I'm on the hunt for a better, stronger grinder. This one lasted less than about 10-mos. I only use it once every 2-wks to grind 24oz of coffee beans to Turkish grind... that's a powdery grind. It takes about 10-15 min each bag. So, basically, I got 330-min of life from this appliance. At the price I paid for it, which was $10 less than it's currently being sold on Amazon, that means it cost me .81-cents to grind each bag of coffee. That's not great... there's got to be something better.

If it's an appliance you keep it in the pantry just in case, it will be fine, but get it at a discounted price. It's certainly not worth $28. For me, it wasn't worth $18.

1* out of 5. It will work, it just won't stand up to much use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Basic No-Frills Medium-Blend Coffee Bean Grinder, by Hamilton Beach
reviews.reviewText:
This is a very simple, no-frills basic grinder. Just one on/off button to push.
There's only one grind setting, a kind of medium-coarse that's OK for a drip coffeemaker. I'm not able to achieve a fine, espresso-type powdery result with this machine.
The 'bowl' capacity is fairly small. The motor becomes warm after a few uses. I had a 2 pound bag of beans to grind up, and halfway through this unit become sufficiently 'hot' that I unplugged it and let it cool down for 20 minutes before resuming the grinding.

It's not a bad little basic unit. But I wound up returning it and paying the few extra dollars to buy the KRUPS grinder instead, which I think is a better unit overall.
These have tiny little motors that sound like they are really laboring to do the job.
I am not impressed, honestly, with any of the grinders that are currently available. The KRUPS unit seems like the best of a mediocre lot.

I give this 4 Stars because it does work. I'd give it 5 Stars if it offered a choice of grinds (Coarse/Medium/Fine).

I hope this is helpful as you comparison shop online. Happy brewing, everybody.

reviews.reviewTitle: wonderful push-top-down electric grinder of 15 years finally quit working
reviews.reviewText: Our old, wonderful push-top-down electric grinder of 15 years finally quit working. Imagine our surprise when we discovered these models are now rare. Instead there are "improved" models, such as this Hamilton Beach grinder, with "features" that will drive you nuts. Firstly, it holds about 1/3 fewer coffee beans than our previous model. The "removable" inner basket will fall out if you tilt the container too much. The "locking" outer lid will challenge you until you either read the multi-page "how-to" booklet (really, who wants a user guide for a coffee grinder?) or luck into figuring it out after a few failures. The "tidy" pull-up mechanism for hiding the cord (really? we need hidden cords?) will drive you nuts if all you want to do is plug the damn thing in and have it go. The good news? It does grind coffee beans. On the other hand, based on how the motor sounds, I'm betting this one won't last nearly as long as our old grinder. Save yourself some money and look elsewhere.

This is my second one in less than a YEAR! Repeat, my second one in a YEAR and it’s already broken. Poor quality. I’d you want something that lasts longer than 6 months then this is not the product for you. We use it about 5 days a weeks. For 30 seconds a day and now it won’t grind. Same issue as our last one 11 months ago.

ok updated september 5, 2018. this one (3rd product) purchased in jan 2018. broken again. on hold with hamilton beach AND PRODUCT IS STILL UNDER WARRANTY! but want me to pay 12.00 dollars shipping to replace this 12 dollar product!!!

We have used Krups in our family for years. When that gave out I wanted a grinder that was

- compact,
- inexpensive
- easy to use and clean
- grinds coffee, spices and nuts.

The REMOVABLE GRINDING CUP makes it easy to scoop in the coffee beans or spices instead of pouring it in and getting stuff all over the counter. It also makes it easy to pour into the contents into another container without having to pick up the whole unit. AND this removable grinding cup it makes it easy to clean between using it for spices or coffee.

The cord can be lengthened or shortened and stored in the bottom that twists down and then back up. This way when using you keep the cord at the length you want and when storing don't have to wrap the cord around the body of the appliance.

We love it - it is compact, quiet and easy to use and clean.

HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

reviews.reviewTitle: WASTE OF MONEY - DIED AFTER 10 MONTHS.
reviews.reviewText:
So disappointed in this product. It worked fine up until its last days... Unfortunately its last day was just 10 months into owning it. I'm the only coffee drinker in our household and I make a single cup every day, so it was not used excessively. Even so, it just stopped working, no warning.

What do you do with a $15 appliance that stops working? You throw it out. Just add it to the landfills... it disgust me. I wish I spent a little more money to get a quality appliance that would last over time. Don't make my mistake.

Great concept. Cheap, unreliable construction. I wanted to use this as a spice grinder, so I liked that the blade and grinding chamber could be removed for easy washing. The retractable cord also looked like a plus in a kitchen with very little counter space. The problem is that this grinder was not durable. Within a couple of weeks the switch fell off the lid assembly and had to be reattached each time I used it. Had I lost that small plastic strip the grinder would have been useless, After about a year the grinder stopped working altogether.

The old Toastmaster electric coffee grinder I have is still going strong after at least a dozen years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Description is for a brand, not a single product.
reviews.reviewText:
Since this review is as random as the description, maybe it's time for Amazon to step up and match descriptions to one product? Otherwise, just don't bother. See below

"Some coffee bean grinders even include a stainless steel grinding chamber that comes out for easy cleanup in the dishwasher."

This is a great feature. Too bad you cannot tell what it applies to.

Purchased this grinder because it was the cheapest one available and we were on a tight budget. Didn't expect it to last long, but over a year later it's still grinding it's little heart out. I love the removable chamber, this feature makes it SO easy to pour the grinds out (especially early, when coffee is needed most) and makes cleanup quick and painless.

What it doesn't tell you here is that the power cord wraps around the bottom in a hidden storage compartment. That little gray plastic area at the base? With a gentle pull it slides down, exposing the power cord. It's not outrageously long our inconveniently short, and the plug just sticks out the back, not too loose, not too tight. Very good for storing without a big cord mess in the cupboard, or having to try to wrap it awkwardly around the outside. Also great for portability.

When this one finally does give out, I'll definitely buy the same model to replace it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Way Way Way better than the Bodum I had!!!!
reviews.reviewText: I needed a grinder asap so went to Walmart to buy a Cuisinart. Their shelf was bare except for this Hamilton Beach. I grind flaxseeds almost every day and and the HB grinds the seeds way way better. I can also tell it will be far easier to clean and the design is better. ( I lost a piece of the Bodum down the drain.) The cord appeared to be REAL short until my boyfriend showed me that it was stored in the base.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grinding leaves something to be desired
reviews.reviewText: I previously had a Krups coffee grinder since 1990. It finally died, and I went to replace it. I bought the Hamilton Beach because the price was reasonable, and had previous good experience with the brand. I liked that the grinding bowl could be taken out to clean it. However, the way it grinds the beans is no good. Either they are overground, and the coffee is too strong, or they leave whole beans after grinding. There seems to be no in-between. With the old one, even though there wasn't a setting for the strength of the coffee, I knew when it made a certain sound, it was finished, and completely ground. With this, it might make a similar sound, but it is not done. I am very unhappy with the purchase, and looking to buy something else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lower Capacity and Shorter Life Than Other Brands
reviews.reviewText: I bought a similar model at Wallmart about 18 months ago. It ground coffee OK, but after that time the plastic shank from the motor part that engages the grinder part broke. I could not repair it with hot glue or glue, so out it went. Also note that the bean capacity is less than some other brands (such as my trusty old Delonghi.) It ground enough Starbucks French Roast beans for 4 10 Oz cups. My ancient spare DeLonghi does about 1/3 more.
This grinder is perfect for a course grind for my French press. It will work for a coffee machine, but you won't get a fine grind for an espresso machine.

This would be a great little grinder except for two things: One, the power cord need to be about a foot longer and two, the grinding cup need to be about a half inch deeper. It does a great job grinding the coffee and it's quiet. I especially like the removable grinding cup because now I don't have to turn the thing upside down to get the coffee out. Just remove the grinding cup and dump it into the maker (which is why the grinding cup needs to be a little higher.
The button broke off. The warranty was a farce. They wanted me to cut off the cord, send them a picture, then pay for all the shipping (cheaper to just buy a different one.)

I purchased this grinder 2 years ago. Cord was short....but it did it’s job and I was happy with it.....until.... the grind button on the front fell off. My very handy husband tried to no avail to fix it. Machine was not abused nor was it used daily. Liked it when it worked—now looking for a teplacement

(Bought this in town, not on Amazon--but I wanted to warn people!)

We loved it... UNTIL is SHORTED with a LOUD POP! Wire was completely frayed in one section--even though it worked perfectly for about a year.

Was quite scary and I had pay to have an electrician come and fix my outlet.

reviews.reviewTitle: I had this for over a year. It worked ...
reviews.reviewText: I had this for over a year. It worked well while it lasted (used 2-4 times per week) but one day stopped and never started again. Pros: grinds well and fast. Cons: doesn't hold a lot of coffee beans per grind. With more frequent use, per other reviews on here, it possibly wouldn't have lasted as long as it did. Not ideal, obviously.

This was my first coffee grinder. I am no coffee aficionado, so basic operation works for me. I also use it to pulverize barley seeds and flax seed for bread. It lasted over a year before it just conked out, dead. I was mad, especially since I couldn't take it apart to see what happened. Elsewhere here I read how you can remove the bottom cover triangular slot out with a small flat screwdriver, and that the switch gets blocked with debris. However, with mine, a wire inside was broke. By testing the wire continuity with a voltmeter, I found that there is a little fuse-like attachment in one of the wire that was broken. A quick solder job and the thing is working again. Inside the motor looks very good in quality and was practically new. Why throw it away in a land fill when you can fix it. Was it designed to blow that fuse after a period of time? I never saw a fuse like that before on an appliance motor, pre-China -- those motors lasted a decade until the brushes wore away.

I have this and a Krups GX4100. I like this Hamilton Beach 80335 much better.

The grind quality is similar and the Krups is a little larger capacity, but the Hamilton Beach never makes a mess... whereas the with the Krups I'm always get grinds on my countertop.

The way the HB's lid slips OVER the grinder means you don't get ground coffee in the seal between the cup and the ginrder the way you do with the Krups. For the same grind, I'll take neatness over un-needed extra volume every day.

reviews.reviewTitle: Chamber gets stuck like it's been glued in place every time.
reviews.reviewText: Grinds beans well but it's become a life and death struggle to remove the grinding chamber. By the time you do get it out grinds are flung everywhere. I shouldn't have to work this hard for a cup of coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Used it for a week, gave up
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this locally for about $15 to replace our Proctor Silex/Hamilton Beach E160B grinder, which started making funny noises after at least 12 years of daily use.

This new one is much, much noisier, has a cord that's too short to use comfortably, and can't grind beans fine enough for espresso without caking the grounds to the bottom and sides.

I am so pleased that they still make the E160B. I'm ordering one today. It's not only a far superior grinder, it costs $5 less than this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does what it meant to do
reviews.reviewText: Pros: lasted several years. Cons: Not easy to clean once stuff gets under the grinding bowl, since it is removable. But overall worked fine.

reviews.reviewTitle: My favourite part is that the cup comes out and you ...
reviews.reviewText: My favourite part is that the cup comes out and you can pour the grinds into the coffee pot unlike others where the entire unit has to be dumped. After a year it still works great. Only issue is if I fill cup with beans the grinds tend to overfill the cup and I lose some on the countertop so you can't grind a full cup of beans for a large pot of coffee. That's not a problem for me.

Broke after six months.. I would expect this product to last longer than that!! Nothing like getting up from a horrible night with your dying dog expecting to brew a decent cup off coffee to give you a little boost ...only to find out your coffee grinder stopped working,... bummer

I originally purchased this to replace my everyday grinder that broke. I was torn between a few, but went with this one because it was inexpensive. I was so pleasantly surprised!!! I have never heard a coffee grinder so quiet! My daughter (2years old) was scared of how noisey my last one was that I could only grind coffee when she was sleeping and with the tv running or when she would covered her ears. I ground about 1-1.5lbs tonight and didnt even bother her!!! Innovative, and inexpensive, not cheap!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not the one I ordered but this is a better model. WIN!WIN!
reviews.reviewText: Ordered this back in 2012. Still going strong. I use it for grinding peppercorns and coffee beans from BLACK RIFLE COFFEE COMPANY. Grind 2-3 times a week. Great grinder. Just wipe out with a paper towel.

reviews.reviewTitle: More like a centrifuge than a grinder.
reviews.reviewText: Garbage. I gave my old coffee grinder away, and darn it she won't give it back when I found out how bad this one is.. The old one worked fine. You pressed the lid and the grind was complete depending on how long you left it on. On this piece of garbage you have to do short bursts, and hope you don't overgrind and turn coffee into dust. Every time it's different. If you just press the button, the grinder just spins the coffee around like a centrifuge. I did give it 2 stars since it hasn't broken.
I use it as herbs and spices grounder.

reviews.reviewTitle: short lived AND very limited use, this is total junk!
reviews.reviewText:
This machine has eaten what I believe is a plastic bearing in cup assembly. This is totally unusable after 16 months of very light and limited usage described below.

I use this on the weekends and ONLY on the weekends. By my count that is 2 days a week.
I make one brew per day on the weekend. I weight the beans (18 grams) on an accurate digital scale. This quantity of beans is less than half of the rated capacity. I can imagine my use is equal to that of a heavy coffee drinker could give this machine in a couple of weeks to a month or 2 at most. ALSO, I don't use it every weekend either - I have some coffee that I purchased in the ground form - no grinding needed.

By the way I checked, I can find the replacement assembly I need, it is $9.99 plus shipping (ups ground is $12.40 ) and (usps is $8.35).
Your shipping cost may vary based on distance, I write this on 06-02-2013. For me this is virtually the cost of an entire new device, if I shop carefully I could possibly buy a complete new unit for less than the cost to get the part in my hand to add to my now old other parts, how long will they last?.

I can not recommend this model to anyone for any reason, it has no value at all except for the very limited use I did get - which is far too short. I would not buy it again. I will not buy the repair assembly as I expect it to do the same thing as the original. If asked for my opinion I would call this total junk. I could add photos of melted plastic bits - is there a point?

I've only used this a few times, just to grind flax seeds to make an egg substitute for vegan gingerbread recipes. It's much better for this than the Mr Coffee grinder: it's simpler to use, the cord is longer, and it does a much better job. It's also faster and a lot less effort than crushing the seeds with a mortar and pestle!

This product showed it's safety hazard standpoint right from the start. I plugged it in without the cap being on it and it
started grinding on it's own. Luckily I had not put any bean in yet. I wondered how it could start without the cap and attached
start button even on it. I put beans in it and it started grinding with the beans in it. I stopped the process in while attempting
to tap the sides of the grinder to get unbroken beans more centrally located, the grinder took off again with me no where near the
"start button". It is not really a button, just a place to touch. If the cheap plastic cap grooves don't line up exactly with the base,
it won't work and you have to fiddle with them till they do. The way that it's made, fine ground coffee can get into the top edges so that
the cap won't fit. I will not have this product long enough to have proof of that. It's going back today.
I would not recommend this product to anyone.

I like the grinding quality and relatively quiet motor on this product. I've docked it a star however because it seems a bit of a challenge to remove the lid from the grinding chamber without coffee grounds dropping all over the countertop. If I can learn the trick to using it without that happening, I'll sing much higher praises for it. But for 15 bucks, this thing does do a good job of handling the morning grind.
good

reviews.reviewTitle: Hamilton Beach 80335 Fresh Grind Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: Never read so many blogs here by a bunch of first class whiners. Do you all want some cheese to go with that WHINE of yours? Yes true you get what you pay for. I got mine as a gift 2 xmas's ago. Still going strong and absolutely no issues. Would I buy another one if this one puked out on me? Oh H*** yea. Only thing I will say when you are done grinding your beans before you take the top off take the heal of your hand and tap the side of it before you take the top off. Otherwise you will get coffee all over your counter. But I think all the grinders are like this. On an ending note here; QUIT YOUR WHINING!!

I did not buy this product through Amazon, I purchased it at Walmart. It's a piece of junk! I've had it maybe two months and it just stopped working in mid-grind. No wierd smell or strange sounds. Just quit. I can't easily take it back as I'm now living in Mexico and don't have the reciept anyway. So hopefully this will deter someone else from making the mistake of buying this piece of junk.

reviews.reviewTitle: The grind was perfectly fine, but this thing was definitely​ NOT built to ...
reviews.reviewText: Does not last. I've had this for MAYBE 6 months, used it once a day on average to grind coffee and sometimes flax, and it just stopped working. It showed no signs of failing, just quit. The grind was perfectly fine, but this thing was definitely​ NOT built to last.

reviews.reviewTitle: It was working great for expresso
reviews.reviewText:
It was working great for expresso. Then after 2 weeks or so, it stopped in the middle of a grind.
Opened it to check it out, no risk at this point. Something in the winding of the motor gave out.
I was disappointed.

reviews.reviewTitle: It broke within first use. I pressed the grind ...
reviews.reviewText: It broke within first use. I pressed the grind button and it just popped off. Unfortunately due to my busy schedule I was unable to send it back for a new one. Obviously its a cheaper grinder, but I thought I'd at least have it a year!

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible product. Locking the lid into place is a ...
reviews.reviewText:
Terrible product. Locking the lid into place is a problem; if it's not perfectly lined up or locked just right, pressing the grind button does nothing. Also, after I'd only used it a couple months, the grind button stopped working altogether.

Junk.
broke after 2 times used, made sound but had that 'something on fire' smell.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hamilton Beach Grinder with removable grinding chamber
reviews.reviewText:
Really Good Coffee is a big part of my daily life. I love coffee.

I bought one of these Hamilton Beach HB Coffee Grinders in black because it was available, not because I had planned to do so. It was an impulse buy at the time.

We needed to buy a grinder after we left a house-share situation with a very sophisticated grinder that we had grown accustomed to using. Due to extensive travel over the last few years, our regular coffee and kitchen equipment is in storage over 1000 miles from our current location.

We purchased this Hamilton Beach grinder about 6 or 7 months ago and we paid about $14.95 plus tax.

At the time of purchase, we figured if it lasted a few months we would be satisfied and we would have received our money's worth. It's now ~7 months later, and we use this grinder everyday for grinding whole bean coffee for "one-off" cups which we brew utilizing a "Melita style" drip system. We have chosen this brewing format because it is a portable system and it packs well in our suitcases.

We travel now with this kit in our suitcases:

Melita style drip plastic cone (paper filter holder)
Melita style paper filters (#2)
Hamilton Beach HB Coffee Grinder Black
Whole Bean Coffee of choice (French Roast Blend)

If we are limited on baggage capacity we can buy coffee at the destination although sometimes we have found it difficult to locate good coffee upon arrival - depending on the location - so we have learned to always travel with enough whole bean coffee to get us by for a week or so.

Thus we are able maintain a level of quality in the coffee we drink regardless of location, whether we are staying in hotel, a friend's house, or in a foreign country. We did recently travel to Costa Rica for 3 months and made the mistake of not taking paper cone filters with us or the Melita cone and were unable to find either anywhere to buy.

We did, however, take our Hamilton Beach grinder with us.

SERVICE LEVEL:

We do not use this grinder a great deal. It's usually for enough whole bean coffee to make 6-8 cups a day so that each cup is freshly ground and brewed from scratch every time.

Occasionally, I use the grinder to grind up nuts or herbs/breadcrumbs/seasoning combinations for breading meats when cooking. But the vast majority is for whole bean coffee only. And I prefer not to infuse the seasonings flavor into the coffee. But it does work pretty well for that application and if I were going to do that frequently, I would buy another grinder dedicated to that application only.

FEATURE:

One of the coolest features of the grinder is "removable grinder chamber" that makes it very convenient for dispensing the ground beans when I finish grinding them. I simply remove the chamber and take it to the location of the cup and Melita cone and it minimizes the mess and the cleanup. I like this design feature very much.

Conclusion: Strongly Recommend

This is not a heavy duty piece of equipment. Yet is is an example of good engineering and design. It is practical, functional and quite inexpensive. I am very satisfied with the Hamilton Beach and recommend it highly for the application described.

Just as a note, I used to own an espresso shop and I still have a commercial espresso machine and a Mazzer burr grinder (that I love) but currently they are in storage.

Regards from sunny Florida...
So quiet. Grinds great.

reviews.reviewTitle: Okay grinder, but the cord is ridiculously short.
reviews.reviewText: The longer I use this, the more I dislike it. It does alright, but I've spilled more than a little grounds when the cord stops my movement.

This is an inferior product, purchased elsewhere as it was all they had, it stopped grinding on the second use and smelled like burning plastic. I will be buying a Krups grinder today, a product I can highly recommend.
I used this 2-3 times a week. It quit working one month and 8 days after the one year warranty expired. If you drink coffee regularly then do not buy this grinder. It is also difficult to operate.
Works perfectly!

I have purchased several Hamiltion Beach products over the past year. Both the coffee grinder and steam iron have proven to be pieces of junk. Hamilton Beach once had a good reputation, I will always avoid buying their products in the future. Not only is the product junk, the support and warranty is not any better. They want you to pay for shipping, both directions for warranty replacement.
The coffee grinder was rarely used, I bet less than 25 times and it just quit working. Of course the plastic body is sealed so you cannot inspect or attempt to repair. It just goes in the garbage.
The steam iron was worse. It over heated. Getting so hot is scorched the ironing board cover as soon as it touch. I had to unplug the power button would not respond. When turned back on, it now leaks although I tossed it after the overheating. HB warranty department said to cut off the cord, send them a picture and they would replace with the same or similar piece of junk.

I think this coffee grinders works reasonably well if you want to just grind a little bit of coffee for your French press. Easy to use, and is compact. However I think ours broke way too fast- 3 years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great if you have an 8 cup coffee maker.
reviews.reviewText: I can't understand why the base holding area isn't at least an inch taller! Obviously, Hamilton Beach decided that everyone prefers weak to medium strength coffee. Notice how the beans are mounded inside it on the picture? I have to grind coffee beans twice since we like strong French roast and have a 12 cup coffee maker. It's not what you would expect when you buy a grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Yes its a cheap pdoduct, and it might need ...
reviews.reviewText: Yes its a cheap pdoduct, and it might need fixing after a few times used. But its such a simple construction that anyone who has basic understanding of household electronics can do it. Just NEVER plug into any other current than 110 volt! I live in Europe and got a US model, had to redo the internal wiring after it was plugged into 220 volt for afew seconds. But otherwise its ok, after all waht can you expect for THAT price!

I originally gave the product a good review, however, after only two months the product gave up the ghost. I then went to Lowes and purchased a Kitchenaide coffee grinder which is well made and does a great job.

DO NOT buy this grinder. It is inexpensive, but you will wind up paying more in frustration. I used it a few times, then it seemed broken, but I got it to start a few more times, and then dead. In contrast, I have had a Braun grinder for about 35 years, and it is still working, but I needed a grinder for a 2nd house and my local store did not have Braun, so I tried this instead. After it broke, I bought a Kitchen-Aid, and it has been fine for the last 2 years.

This coffee grinder lasted me 5 months, then the grinding base busted out, also the seal of the blade tore up. I hand washed it all the time, and allowed it to dry before using it.
If you are looking for something quieter and more durable, look elsewhere. It doesn't have different settings for various grinds. It's a basic, and poorly made product.

Brought this 3 weeks ago or so. Have used it 3 times for making breadcrumbs...so not a heavy duty use. It just started smoking and burned out. Not sure if I still have the receipt but am very disappointed.

I've had this grinder for a couple of months, used it about 3 times - mainly to grind spices (mostly cardamom - which isn't too hard at all).

Although, it does an amazing job of grinding, the product-parts are not durable.

After using a couple of times, and washing it, the edges of the grinder cup and the lid too are showing cracks.

The base allows cord storage (a good idea), but the underside is smooth which makes it slippery.

Pros:
1) The coffee grinder cup is removable, and can be washed separately without having to hassle with the motor base
2) Cord storage

This grinder does a very good job of grinding but it is extremely loud and vibrates so much that holding on to it is like nails on a chalkboard. This thing will wake you up in the morning long before your coffee has brewed!

Great grind but obnoxiously loud and physically vibrates to the point of uncomfortable
After two months of daily use, the grinder died. It was blowing smoke out from the bottom
worked for less than 6 months and do not cover the guarantee in Venezuela, not recommend it ...

I have had this product for a little less than 1 year, and used it only about 20 times. The jar now has cracks all around it. It has become hard to close the lid.
Like most coffee bean grinders, this one also spills the ground coffee/spices out of the jar.
I am not happy with this because of the duration it lasts. Definitely not recommended.
This product died after about 10 uses. Right in the middle of grinding, it just stopped. Not much more to say than that.
Average quality which you can expect at this price...

I got mine at WalMart, but felt compelled to write a review here anyway. I'll chime in with the "junk" crowd. I use mine to make dubbing for fishing flies.
Basically you cut short pieces of yarn and spin them up in the grinder making a fluffy ball. Small pieces of that can be wound onto a hook to make the body of a fly.
The machine worked pretty well for a while, but now it has loosened up a bunch, and sometimes the blades won't spin at all. I have found very small bits of plastic in the cup too. I think it's about toast. It's a mystery to me how such an absolute POS can generate a 4 star rating on Amazon. What corporate strategy says it's a good idea to manufacture a product guaranteed to fail within a year? Why aren't they recalling the product? Have they no pride in their company at all? I think the question answers itself. What a time we live in.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hamilton Beach coffee grinders are poor products
reviews.reviewText:
The first one I bought from Walmart failed after a few weeks. I bought it again, again quite disappointing - makes quite a lot of noise, not like as it is advertised. I used to own a Braun and a Krups, both lasted for years without any problem.

I wouldn't recommend Hamilton Beach products.
Failed after 8 months.
If you read the instructions and follow the guidelines, you can't go wrong. LOVE this grinder!

reviews.reviewTitle: Ground coffee. Lasted a few months. Not even worth $0.
reviews.reviewText: A weird plastic bearing broke so it doesn't spin anymore. I don't know why they would be so cheap as to use soft plastic for the part that decides whether the grinder is going to spin or not, but they did so this grinder isn't even worth the cup of coffee you'll have to go out and buy when you can't grind your coffee one morning.
Good
Used it less than 20 times and it just stop working
Excellent
I needed an inexpensive grinder for spices. Works great!

qAndA.question: Hi. Supports 220v/110v? Or only 110v?
qAndA.answer: The box says 120V

qAndA.question: What is the wattage of this grinder?
qAndA.answer:
115 watts
120V~60Hz 125W

qAndA.question: I cannot pull the electric cord out of the grinder, the maximum lenght is 3 inches, I missed something? I tried push it in before pull it out, yank it

qAndA.question: Can you adjust how coarse or fine you want your coffee beans in this model?

qAndA.question: New unit out of the box had coffee grind dirt trapped between the metal grind chamber and the plastic. Anyone know how to clean it?
qAndA.answer: Take the cup out of the grinder and turn the cup upside down. There are 4 screws which secure the metal cup to the plastic cup. Remove these screws and you can pull the two apart. Make sure that both are very dry before putting them back together. (Don't over tighten the screws - it can crack the plastic.)

If its ground fine, the powder sticks to the sides of the chamber and on the blades. For food items, if I don't get it all off its no big deal, but medicine dose is more precise.
